Iterators

What are iterators?

Iterators are objects similar to pointers in the way that they point to other objects; however the main difference between iterators and pointers is that iterators is its own class and can be bi-directional if you implement your iterator class to do so.

Ranged for loops with iterators

In our course, we will mainly use iterators to allow the implementation of ranged-for loops for collections. For this, our iterator class should include 3 parts: an equality operator, dereference operator, and the ++ operator. The iterator should also store a data pointer to the current object and have a constructor.

Begin() and end()

The collection that utilizes the iterator should have 2 other methods: begin() and end(). Begin() should return an iterator that points to the memory address of the first element of the collection and end() should return the memory address after the memory address of the last element of the address. You can think of begin() and end() as defining a half-open range where it is inclusive on the side of begin() and exclusive on end(). Once you reach the end(), you know that you are out of bounds and should stop.

Declaring STL iterators

If you import an STL container (for example in the line " #include <vector&rt "), you can call its iterator by writing "::iterator" after the STL object. For example, "vector< char > :: iterator" .

If you need a const iterator (so that you can treat the item the iterator is pointed to as const), "::const_iterator"
